snippet: After an avalanche swept through the tiny village of Sherin Nazim on Monday, 47 of the roughly 200 residents were believed to be dead.
abstract: Avalanche that crushed a village in the far reaches of northern Afghanistan, killing at least 50 people, is part of a pattern of extreme temperatures and heavier snowfall that has spread suffering and underscored the government’s continued failings despite a decade of outside assistance and billions of dollars in aid; relief groups and aid workers are bracing for flooding.

byline.contributor: Alissa J. Rubin and Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul, and an employee of The New York Times from Kunduz, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: After an avalanche swept through the tiny village of Sherin Nazim on Monday, 47 of the roughly 200 residents were believed to be dead.

headline.seo: Afghan Avalanche Exposes Vagaries of Climate and of Aid
headline.main: Avalanche Exposes Afghans’ Vulnerability to Vagaries of Climate and of Aid
headline.print_headline: Avalanche Exposes Afghans’ Vulnerability to Vagaries of Climate and of Aid
